Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Plasmonic Nanoantenna-Based Multiplexing microRNA Assay at Zeptomolar Concentrations

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Sardar, Rajesh
Proposal Number: 1604617

MicroRNAs are small nucleic acid strands that are becoming important in understanding fundamental biological pathways and disease diagnostics. The proposed work will attempt measuring them using a technique that is expected to yield very high sensitivity in biological samples.

MicroRNAs (miRs) are single-stranded RNAs, capable of regulating genomic processes. Their measurement is useful in disease diagnosis, including cancer. Thus circulating miRs have the potential to serve as diagnostic markers. The current state-of-the-art miR assay is by qRT-PCR, requiring reverse transcription, labeling and amplification. Preliminary studies suggest that hybridizing miR to single-strand DNA (ssDNA) that is attached to gold nanoprisms (GNPs) may induce a novel transduction mechanism via delocalization of conduction electrons. This electronic effect can be investigated utilizing localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) properties of GNPs bound to solid substrates. It is found that GNPs undergo a large LSPR wavelength shift upon ssDNA/miR hybridization, and is thought to be due to electronic delocalization, and is an unexplored methodology for analyzing miRs in biological fluids. Further, there is a potential to develop this new methodology into a label-free, low cost multiplexing array. This proposal seeks to validate the electronic delocalization hypothesis by investigating spacing/electronic conjugation between ssDNA and the GNP surface, a single mismatch at different positions in ssDNA/miR helix, chemical functionality attached to ssDNA, and number of nucleotides in miR strands, for structural characterization of the LSPR-based sensors. The proposed research will result in LSPR-based miR sensors capable of assaying at ultralow concentrations in biofluids (Objective 1) via UV-visible spectrometry by monitoring changes in the LSPR peak. To achieve multiplexing capability, portability and long-term stability, GNPs will be immobilized at the bottom of plastic multiwall plates. In this way, each well can be treated as an independent miR sensor (Objective 2). It is expected that assay of 50 distinct miRs excluding positive and negative controls directly from biofluids using a single 96-well plate, and will be characterized in absorption mode by a standard plate reader. Such a design is expected to impact both biomedical research and medical diagnostics. Research activities will involve high school, undergraduate, and graduate students through mentored projects, and the research data will be integrated into existing courses. Nanoscience will be more broadly promoted to middle and high schools through training school teachers in nanostructure synthesis and women in science symposium

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was inspired by the unique localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) properties of noble metal nanostructures coupled with the charge transport ability of duplex DNAs. The overarching goal of the project was to develop an ultrasensitive label-free biosensor for the detection and quantification of microRNAs utilizing the LSPR properties of gold triangular nanoprisms (Au TNPs). MicroRNAs are short non-coding RNAs, which regulate various cellular processes and have been identified as biomarkers for the detection of cancer as well as associated with disease progression and metastatic processes. One advantage of using this label-free optical based assay over current polymerase chain reaction (PCR) technique is crude human biofluids (plasma and blood) specimens can be analyzed without extensive sample processing for highly effective liquid biopsies for clinical cancer diagnosis. The project proposed to accomplish two objectives: (1) Develop an ultrasensitive microRNA nanoplasmonic biosensor by elucidating the LSPR-based sensing mechanism; (2) Fabricate a multiplexing and high-throughput biosensor. The multiplexing and high-throughput nanoplasmonic biosensor would then be used to test and evaluate real clinical patient samples (Bladder cancer patients? plasma samples).

 The first objective was accomplished by examining the mechanism of DNA mediated charge transport that significantly altered the free electron density of Au TNPs (?plasmoelectric effect?, Figure 1A). By programmable manipulation of the structure of receptors (-ssDNA), the sensitivity of the nanoplasmonic biosensor was achieved in the zeptomolar range.  A surprising discovery was that the developed nanoplasmonic biosensors were capable of distinguishing microRNAs with single nucleotide specificity. The ultrasensitive assay allowed for the detection and quantification of both tumor suppressor microRNAs (the level of microRNA decreases in cancer patients as opposed to normal healthy individuals). Experimentally quantifying the level of both oncogenic (the level of microRNA increases in cancer patients relative to normal healthy individuals) and tumor suppressor microRNAs, significantly reduces the possibility of false responses and greatly increases accuracy in the early detection of metastatic bladder cancer.  

 Next, the group developed multiplex and high-throughput biosensors in a 96-well format, which were capable of detection and quantification of at least 20 cancer patient samples and 4-microRNA panels in a single instrument run (Figure 1B). The selectivity of this multiplex and high-throughput assay enhanced the selectivity of disease diagnosis substantially, specifically differentiating between healthy individual and patients with non-metastatic bladder cancer, thus representing an advanced technology for non-invasive liquid biopsy. Biosensors that were designed and fabricated are reproducible and stable for up to a month and have seven order of dynamic linear ranges.       

 The broader impact of the project was spread throughout the community. Female and underrepresented minority undergraduate students, through NSF-led program, learned how to synthesize efficient nanomaterials for biosensing applications. In addition, high school students through the American Chemical Society-SEED program gained authentic research experience in synthesizing and analyzing nanomaterials and fabricating high-throughput biosensors for clinical cancer diagnosis. Through weekly group meetings and collaborations between students, theoretician, and scientists from the national laboratory, students were able to receive enhanced laboratory training and gained a diverse perspective from all who participated. Results were also incorporated into college level classes on optoelectronic properties of nanomaterials and bioanalytical assay for disease diagnosis.
